The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:Glass that hasn't been treated to be extra strong is what? Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: What is the area of this triangle (without trig or complex functions)?<n>Answer: 0.4<n><n>Input: What’s 1/3 of 2 + 3/6 of 5 - 1/4 of 5 - 4/5 of 6?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>Input: What percentage of 32% is 29%?<n>Answer: 94.32%<n><n>Input: If you spend 25% of your income on food and 56% is utilities, how much is left for your savings?<n>Answer: 19%<n><n>Input:  The price of a new book is 5 dollars. The book sells at a 40% discount. How much would it cost to purchase the book if you use a 30% discount?<n>Answer: 5.30<n><n>Input:  It costs $390 to fill a 4 wheeler and 50% of that amount, what price will the new 3 wheeler cost?<n>Answer: 0<n><n>Input: You have 0.31 miles to go in your car to get to work. You can drive an average of 40 miles per hour and you’re traveling with other passengers. What is the largest number of people you can have as passengers in your car to reach your destination?<n><n>Answer: (Total of 0.31/40) = (X) / (40+X) = (0.084) / (40 + 0.084 ) = 0.47 = X<n><n>Input: The total cost of a group order of a sandwich was $34.50. There were 7 sandwiches and 2 drinks which cost $1.60 each. What was the total cost for the drinks<n>Answer: ($1.60*2) = 3.20<n><n>Input: What was the total mileage of the trip to Mt. Rushmore?<n>Answer: 800.0<n><n>### Bonus: In each problem below, the question relates to one of the following four sets from the original 4 sets that came with the practice assessment test.<n><n>Set 1 - You have 16 cand

The first group is in the tens place and the rest in the ones place.<n>Group 1: 1200 + 9410 + 9900 + 8532 + 971 + 4545<n>Group 2: 2841<n><n>### Response<n>The total value of Group 1 is 49913.<n>A person who gets the first three digits of this value can choose one of Group 1 and Group 2 as their desired value.<n>If Group 2 is chosen, the next person who wants to have a number from 49914 to 1000 will choose one digit from Group 2.<n>If the person gets a duplicate number, then the next number in Group 1 will be chosen.<n><n>### Input and response example<n>Person 1: I want 49<n>Person 2: Let's get 85 and 99<n>Person 3: I take the 4 in front and the 6, 7, 7, 9, 9, 0, 0, and also the 6, 1, 2 and 7, 2 in the 80s of the tens place<n>Person 4: What I will get is 94<n>Person 5: I will get 49<n><n>### Input example<n>What a group does:<n><n>* 1200 to 4545 = 3,345<n>* 1 to 1,000 = 1000<n><n>So:<n><n>* 4545 gets 3,344<n>* 3,346 gets 3,333<n>* 3,232 takes 3,222 from 1 to 100<n>* 3,014 takes all the rest and gets 49<n><n>This will be Group 1 for the next player.<n><n>### Response for Group 1<n><n>* if we look at the second digit we always need to 0 to the left. The rest will be 6. so 45 will get 6045 or 50<n>* if we look to the

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:The camper looked up at the vast night sky, it left him feeling mighty what? Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n><n>### Response:		C<n>

Choices:  A: football stadium B: laboratory C: baseball stadium D: pharmacy E: soccer game<n><n>### Response:		<n>I have seen there is a mistake in the answer to this question, it should be baseball stadium.<n><n>### Input<n>What color is the background of a picture of the Grand Canyon?<n><n>### Response<n>The background is dark.<n><n>### What does the following image describe?<n>What is the total number of blocks on the blue-shaded areas?<n>-<n><img class="img-responsive img-thumbnail" width="250" height="100" src="http://www.flickr.com/groups/challenge/discuss/72157671388973940"><n><n>### Answer:<n>There are 113 blue blocks.<n><n>### Write a Python module named "PuzzlerTest" with the following __doc__:<n>"""<n>A class to solve logic puzzles.<n><n>Usage:<n>    from PuzzlerTest import Puzzler<n><n>solve_a_number_sequence(<string>): solve the numbers in the sequence.<n>solve_the_crossword(<crossword>): solve the words in the crossword.<n>solve_a(<list>): solve the grid in the crossword<n><n><n>The user should be able to call the solve methods with appropriate parameters<n>to: (1) solve a number sequence, (2) solve a crossword, and (3) solve a<n>crossword grid.<n><n>To give an example, from the documentation on the wiki at http://<n>code.google.com/p/fatfish/wiki/Puzzles and with the code posted at<n>http://code.google.com//p/puzzles/source/browse/trunk/:<n><n>>>> puzzler = puzzlerTest.Puzzler()<n>>>> puzzler.solve_the_word_search(word_search)<n>>>> puzzler(word_search) is None<n>True<n>>>> puzzler([22, 8, 2, 4, 2]) is not None<n>True<n>>>>> puzzler(["bicycle", "candle", "shoveled", "window", "bed", "sealed", "pillow", "table"]) is None<n>True<n><n>"""<n><n>### Write the following method

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. How many points does the average team member get in a single round? Do your best to solve this task. See if you can figure out the answer before you read the answer. (See note 1)<n>### Task Outputs : Output 1: 103 Output 2: 21<n>### Task Explanation: Input Average scores per player during a round equals 103 Points.  A round has 4 Bowlers.  To find the average: 103 = 4*103/x x = 417 x = 4 Bowlers Average 103 points each. So answer should be 417 = 103<n><n>### Task Instruction:<n>Write a command that completes the request. <n><n>### Task : When the ball rolled into the ditch, the players knew they’d won. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:He had a hard time finding the room on his schedule, it was on the second floor and he got lost in the very large what? Choices: 0.2 pounds, 40 pounds, 220 pounds, 2 pounds, 80 pounds<n><n>We want to find out how much does Mark weigh now. <n><n>So if Mark weighs 20 pounds now, then we need to choose what is closer than 2 (the 20+2=22 is 20 and the 20-2=18 is 18). <n><n>Therefor Mark weighs 40 pounds. <n><n>### Input & Response:Someone who is sleeping is likely to know where they are because they are this? choices: A: deep sleep B: conscious D: alert E: dreaming<n><n>The answer is C: dreaming. <n><n>When we are sleeping at night, we are in deep sleep and when we are in deep sleep, we are dreaming.

The question asks: <n><n>Can a number n be increased or decreased without changing the answer of the original division problem (n/m)?<n><n>The following answers are incorrect. <n><n>* A: This would be true if both the numerator and the denominator were decreasing.  <n>* B: This is incorrect because it means an increase only, with no decrease.<n>* C: There are no changes here. <n>* D: This will only help for a decrease in both numerator and denominator, as the original equation could change and be incorrect.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>In some cases a program can be written to make two numbers equal. Provide written instructions to assist the reader.<n><n>- Write down the first 20 multi-digit factorial<n>  _-_ Use the formulae, n! = n x (n-1) x (n-2) x … 3 x 2 x 1<n>- Write down the 120 triangle numbers<n>  _-_ The triangle numbers are numbers that start with 1 and double every number in between, starting at 1, and ending with the 120th triangle number<n>- Write down the sum of the first 68 prime numbers<n>  _- _Prime numbers are numbers with factor pairs only of 1 and the number itself<n><n>Example:<n><n>- In a row of 8, how many of the squares will be white?<n>  _-__ 1, 3, 5, 6, 4, 2, 8, 8<n><n>- What is 45.4546546553546654675467565465454675?<n>  _____45.455.46(65467654677/7600443789835/1540005489615)<n><n>- What is the sum of every fourth number from 1 to 108?<n>  ___1, 9, 27, 45, 63, 81, 100, 118, 136, 154, 172, 190, …<n><n>- Find the 10th root of -.75<n>  ___ 0.8223161864199994779305057044012076057991436<n><n>- How many 6 number lottery tickets can you buy for $20?<n>  ___ 2, 18

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:Sam was against Allison's decision.  Joe was the opposite.  What was Joe, regarding that decision? Choices:  A: being for B: away from C: combined D: for or E: conjunction<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Justification: Sam: against, Allison:for <n>Joe is against Sam because Joe is being for Allison,  Jill was combined. Joe didn't say what he was for or against.<n><n><details><n>  <summary>Additional Questions and Response</summary><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a response that appropriately answers each question as written and provide a justification for each response.<n><n>#### Demonstration: (1 Point)<n><n>#### Input:Sam was against (1 Point)<n>Allison's B. Joe was (1 Point)<n>  <n><details><n>    <summary>Show Answer and Justification</summary><n><img src="https://images.ctfassets.net/yb3mrnr6o2sz/26yMNn7945Jzg3qQK6F3nB/859d3dd46742f5eb0a1fb8eb205057e6/instructiondemo.png">  <n></details><n><n>#### Question: What did Allison do? (1 Point)<n><img src=" https://images.ctfonline.com/g/iJF057U-Ih4rBwHp/allisonb.png">   <n>Because Allison's was for, Sam was against. Joe was for Allison.<n><n>#### Instructions:<n>You can change the numbers but not the mathematical relationship.<n>(1 Point)<n><n><table><n>  <thead><n>    <tr><n>    <th>1.</th><n>    <th style="border:none;text-align:right" >C</th><n>    <td></td><n>  </tr><n>  <tr><n>    <!-- Begin Output --><n>    <td style="background:gray;padding:2px;border:1px solid red;border-radius:5px;text-align:left"><img src="http://i0.a.aliimg.com/photo/v0/630351185_642348884.svg" height="60" width="64":<br><img src=" https://www.mathplayground.com

Express the relationship between A and B in terms of A / B, B/A A / D. A multiple choice question will follow.<n>### Answer:<n>```<n>A + B = C + D<n>C = B, but B > D<n><n>A is greater than D<n>B is greater than D<n><n>A / B<n>500 / 180 = 9686.6666667 / 232<n>```<n>##

In how many years is Jessica's birthday before her friend's?<n>Answer:  3 years.<n><n>### Input<n><n>A: If babies are born at 7:00 AM, what is the last possible hour for a baby to be born during the day?<n>```<n>    Choices:  a: 3:10 pm, B: 4:70 pm, C: 5:30 pm, D: 6:10 pm <n>```   <n>B: Write an expression that will compute the minimum number of hours after the 3:00 o'clock that could be the last possible hour for the birth of a baby<n>```<n>    Solution: 3:00 + (3:10 - 3:00)<n>```

Choices:  A: farmland B: neighborhood C: city D: property E: subdivision<n><n>### Response:		 <n><n>### Input Answer:B<n><n>### Demostration Answer:<n>Ex: a yard is tiny for a farmland cause they can grow a lot of grass<n><n>### Instructions Answer:<n><n>### Demosntration Answer:<n>Ex. a yard is tiny for an apartment<n>A yard is a place where you can grow a lot of things and have room for animals.<n><n><n>### Input-Answer:<n><n>### Demo Answer:<n>Farm yards are tiny cause they mainly just grow crops not animals.<n><n>### Input answer:A<n><n>### Demotest response:<n><n>Ex. a yard can be big cause your have a grass and flowers<n>a yard can be tiny cause they can grow some flowers and not too much of anything else

Choices:  A: cabinet B: computer printer C: suitcase D: office supply store E: artist's studio<n><n>### Response:		<n>Let's begin with large pieces of paper that aren't for sale. A) A cabinet would not be a place to find paper that is not for sale, because the drawers in the cabinet are not for sale. B) You probably couldn't find paper that is not on sale in a computer printer, since the printer likely has the capacity to have paper for sale. C) You might be able to find paper for sale in a suitcase, but suitcases are not necessarily very large. D) An office supply store would likely have paper for sale or even large pieces of paper, but they would not necessarily be large pieces of paper that were not for sale. E) An artist's studio is a more likely place to find large pieces of paper that not for sale, because they typically aren't purchased in bulk. Thus, they would have to be purchased for use in the studio, and that would be the case whether the paper was being used to make art or merely used as large pieces of paper.<n><n>### Input #2: <n><n>Two students are on a ski trip with 59 other students.  If 26 students skied down the hill on 21 January, 15 skied down on 20 January and 33 skied down on 19 January, which two students can not have skied on the same day of the ski trip (as of the date of the ski trip)?<n><n>### Response #2:<n>The solution to the above math problem: "26 students ski down the hill in 1 week, the next 15 ski down the next day; then the third group of 33 students ski down the hill 2 days after the previous group.  If each ski day has 26 students on it, then there will be 82 students on the final day of skiing."<n><n>Solution:<n><n>If the same two students skied on each day then they would have skipped 5 days.  Therefore, they could not have both skied the same day during the ski trip, as they are being told on each of the 5 days they were not able to ski.

The second person means to explain something and then the first person says “I don’t think I’m understanding what you mean”.  However, the second person seems to think the person understands and wants to explain it again in more detail.<n><n>B)The first person says “I really can’t understand what it means” and the second person says “I don't think I'm understanding what you mean” and there is a back and forth.  The second person wants the first person to explain to them in more details.<n><n>C)The first person says he doesn’t know what it is, so the second person wants a definition, however the first person says he doesn't understand what that means.  They both want an explanation to the other.<n><n>D)After the second person says "I get it" the first person then says, “I don’t get you” making them both confused.<n><n>E)The first person asks for an explanation and the second person thinks they are confused because they are both giving definitions instead of an explanation of what it means.  The second one then says "I don’t think you get it”, meaning they need to explain it.<n><n>### Can you tell me what is happening in the chat conversation above?<n>The first person asks if the first person can write the program. The second says, “I need you to create a program that finds the difference between two number of times and finds what is the difference then.”  The first person says it is not simple.  The second person gives an example, then the first person says that “I can do it. That won’t be a problem.”  The second person asks when it would get done.  The first person says in 1 to 2 days, then the second person tells them to go to their manager and ask for the details.  They both say “Sure” at the end.<n><n><n>The first person asks for help programming.  The second person says,  “You are going

What is the remainder?<n><n>### Response<n><n>6<n>### Instruction<n><n>Create the following program from these methods.<n><n>Write a method called makeIt() that takes in only one parameter.  Return a string that says, "The makeIt() factory created."<n><n>Write a method that takes in three strings and two parameters.  The strings should be a message to include, a parameter that gets a string that is added to the end of the first parameter, and a parameter that gets a parameter that is subtracted from the last parameter.  The returned string should be, "The string returned" + msg + sub1 + sub2.<n><n>Write a main() method that calls the makeIt() and mashup() methods above. You can then use it to run an example to make sure all of the methods are working.<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```<n>import java.util.Scanner;<n><n>public class Main {<n>	private static Scanner scanner;<n><n>	public static String makeIt() {<n>		return "The makeIt() is working";<n>	}<n><n>	public static void mashup(String msg, String sub1, String sub2) {<n>		return msg + sub1 + "+" + sub2;<n>	}<n><n><n>	public static double mashUp(String msg, String add1, String sub2, float add2) {<n>	  return add1 + "+" + mashup(msg, sub2, add2);<n>	}<n>	<n>	public static void main(String[] args) {<n>		scanner = new Scanner(System.in);<n>		int a;<n>		float b;<n>		String c;<n>		System.out.print("Enter a number: ");<n>		a = scanner.nextInt();<n>		System.console();<n>		<n>		System.in.read();<n>		System Main(String[]);<n>		System.print("Please enter a number: " + a);<n>		System print();<n>		Main m();<n>		Main(String, String, String, String, int, String, String, int, float);<n>	}<n><n>}<n>```<n>

The 100 dollars is paid as a total sum. That is, the 100 dollars that is paid is one amount of 100 dollars. It is not possible to add a 50 dollars of one person's money to a 50 of another person's money and end up with 100 dollars<n><n>### Answer2<n>Two people are making a total sum of 100. By subtraction, one can subtract from 100 to get 50 and to get 55. Therefore, 50 cannot subtract from 55 to get 55, therefore, they have to be two separate values.<n><n>###Instruct 3<n>Answer 1<n><n>- Choice C: Because there is no "equal to" symbol, this is a variable and an expression.<n><n>- Choice D: Because they equal an expression, the answers are correct.<n>	If statement were as follows<n><n>- 1<n><n>- 2<n><n>- 3<n><n>Answer 2<n><n>- Choice B: The sum of (-4x+y+3) and (-6x-6y+8) is incorrect because 6x=y in the first expression and the (-2

Her pet snake is 12 inches long. What is it’s width?<n><n>### Response to instruction:<n>A<n>### Explanations:<n>I can create a question like “”is it correct?” in python then input “answer” to get a y/n answer. If the answer is y then all we have to do is divide 12 by 3 with the result which is the width<n>### Input:Your car is broken down and you're stuck on the side of the road on a hot summer day. Can your phone help you get cool enough to sleep?<n>### Response:Y<n>### Explanatory notes:<n>I can make a formula = input("Type yes/no")(1/3)^(1/2) so i can get a yes or no answer for the if statement. Firstly, create a question “Do you think its greater than 1?” if it is yes continue, if not the program ask the user to try again and continue the loop till it works<n>### 2. If the question is yes, create an if statement <n>### 3. In the if statement, get the input which can be done by the input('input a number')<n>### 4. If the inputted number is 1, display “1 is not greater than” and then try again<n>##

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:The lady was doing a one man show of her tell story, when the show began she did what? Choices:  A: persuade B: slept C: take center stage D: challenge E: speak clearly<n><n>### Response:		The lady took centerstage<n><n>### Input<n>Mark's brother John is very smart, but he always finds a way to mess up the solution to math problems.  John decided to write the following problem on his binder and ask the teacher to solve it. <n>A cowboy wanted to ride his horse to the ranch but there was a large herd of bison blocking the way, and the bison were not moving.  The cowboy had his pistol, and he could shoot all of the buffalo in exactly an hour.  He began riding to and from the herd on the hour, but he was late once and he was too early once during his journey.  How long did it take for him to ride from the ranch to and from the bison herd?<n><n>### Response<n>It took him an hour and 35 minutes<n><n>### Input Mark is the only member of the town team who can throw a football. One day, he's playing his first game for his new team and the captain gives him the option to choose in which direction he wants to throw the ball. <n>The captain of the team has asked Mark which direction he wants the ball to go, where W is north, S is south, E is east, and W is west. The captain has written 10 possible throws from any of the eight positions that Mark can throw from, given by the following strings. Choices: "3 3 E 7 E 9 7 E 7 4 E 5 S 7 E 5 E 3 W 1 S 8 W 5 W 1 1 S 1 3 W 6 6 S"<n><n>Where 3 indicates an east throw, S for south, E for east, 4 for north, and W for west. <n>What is the captain's strategy and what is Mark's strategy?<n><n>### Input The first position is chosen by having the players select any one number from 1 to 10, no repeats. <n>### How many ways can 3 be selected as the first position number?<n>### Marks strategy is<n>1. 3 east if any other player selects 1<n>2. 3 south if any other player selects any number between 2 and 5<n>3. 3 east if the captain selects 6<n>What is the captain’s strategy?<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:When we are thankful for getting something what do we do? Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: When we are thankful for being given something, we smile.<n><n>### Challenge:<n>Input: When your boss tells you you've messed up, what is your first thought. Choices:  A. "why aren't I doing what you tell me to" or "why didn't I think of that" B. "what do i need to do to fix this" or "how did you find out" C. "I can't believe I messed up" or "how long before my next paycheck"<n><n>

Change clothes<n><n>**Explanation:**<n><n>I believe that if we want to help our environment we need to start from within. We do so by using less of what the environment provides us. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:What would form on your feet, if you were jogging all day? Choices:  A: speak freely B: happiness of a child C: care for children D: school child E: control children<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In the instruction it states that a parents duty is to care for children. The instruction has chosen D for option E, but choice D is incorrect.<n><n>The primary purpose is to care for children because as a parent, children are under your care and you are their guardian. Without a parent, children will be left in the streets and will run away from their home where they'll suffer hardships on the street. Children under the care of adults, parents or guardian are more safe and secure than on the street where they might get kidnapped or molested. By raising a child, parents are responsible and accountable to the government or the authority and will be responsible if any harm caused to the child that was in their care.<n><n>The parents have other duties too, such as giving them good education and provide them with a home. It is not enough to just care for them, as their welfare must be taken into consideration. Good education is important when growing up, with or without the help of parents, as they can still find a job when they grow up. Parents must also provide them a home until they'll learn how to take care of themselves when they have grown up.<n><n>### Input;Answer:How much is a 12 pack of beer? Choices: 1: $21 2: $12 3: $73 4: $23 5: $10<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>12 packs of Beer cost around $10. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:What could fighting inflation cause if it is not successful? Choices:  A: problems B: not noticeable C: deflation D: economic instability E: eat cake<n><n>### Response:		Choice B<n><n>### Input<n>Today is your birthday.  Your family is throwing you a party. Do not write a paragraph describing what you did.**  <n>1. **If your response is too long, remove unnecessary words. You can use a thesaurus online to add new words to your vocabulary to help you be more concrete, detailed and/or concise. [140 Charter/Word Count] For example, use a thesauraus online to replace one of the following words with a substitute word: "the", "a", "and", "and/or", "because", "but" and "that".**<n>2. **If your sentence is too complex for vocabulary level, read the sentence as many times as necessary to understand it fully.**<n><n>### Submission:<n>Click Submit Response to submit multiple choice question responses. You will receive an error message if your answer is an invalid answer.<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. A.  What is the sum of your digits?  What is 26?  Write a math equation comparing the two. Does the difference between 15 and 16 have a different sum of the digits?<n>2.  B.  What is the difference between your digits?  What are the numbers?  Is the difference between your number and 15 the same as the difference of the digits in each number?  Is the difference of 15 and your integer is the same as the digits in 16?<n>3.  C.  Is the digit of 15 greater than the digit of one of your numbers?  What is the digit of the other of your numbers?  Is the remainder in the quotient of three greater than the number of digits in one of your numbers?<n><n>### Investigation:<n>Accept answer<n>Answer: You want the sum of the digits in two numbers to be equal to the sum of the digits from 26,<n>so the difference between the digits should be the difference between the two numbers multiplied by 25.<n><n>Reject answer<n>Answer: The question wants to compare the digits of the sum and the digits of 22.<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Choose two of these items<n><n>Items: 1. Example: What is your grade?<n>* You may use the following variables;<n>    * Variable `grade` will hold the value entered by the user.<n>* Write a complete statement. Example: If x < 0, print "The number is negative."<n><n>## Code<n><n>```<n># Program to receive a grade and print a statement for grade < 0<n><n>grade = input("What is your grade?")<n><n>if grade < 0:<n>    print("The number is negative.")<n>else:<n>    print("Great job!")<n>```<n><n>## Output<n><n>```<n>> $ python<n>Welcome to Python 3.6.5 (default, Sep 16 2019, 23:30:31) <n>[Clang 6.0.0 (llvm-10.0.1)] on darwin<n>Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.<n>>>><n>> What is your grade?2<n>The number is negative<n>>>><n>```<n><n>## Demo<n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>What is you gradate?<n>> <n>```<n><n>### Code<n><n>```<n>grade = input("How is your grade?") <n>if grade < 10:<n>    print('Great job')<n>else:<n>    if grade < 20:<n>        print('Good job')<n>    elif grade < 30:<n>        print("It's ok, you have to work harder")<n>    elif

Mary had 89<n>1.  Mary used some stickers<n>2.  Mary used some other stickers<n>3.  How many stickers does mary have remaining?<n><n>### Output: 44<n>### Instruction-Type: MCQ<n>### Score:5/5<n><n>### Note:<n>I read and understand the given instruction and demonstration. Then, I followed the given demonstration to complete the program. Then I answer the question to show a task that demonstrates my understanding of the question.<n><n><n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:What kind of place could have thousands of statue? He had a hangup.  He didn't like to be what? Choices:  A: orgasm B: cum C: naked D: in bed E: wearing his birthday suit<n><n>### Response:		He had a hangup and didn't like to orgasm.<n><n>### Input How much is 3673055508135425972 in binary form? Choices: A: 7B: 5C: 8D: 6E: 4<n><n>### Response How much is 3 billion dollars in binary form? Choice: 8<n><n>### Input Jack’s homework takes 2 hours to do, and each of his friends take 3 hours to do their homework.  They are working together on a project.  How long does the project take them together if Jack works, on average, 12 times slower than his friends do their homework?<n><n>### Response The project takes 3 hours for each of their friends to do. Jack works 12 times slower. That means he takes 3 hours to finish his homework. Total time equals the amount of time he took plus the amount of time his friends took. Total Time = Jack's homework + each of his friends' homeworks. Total time equals 3 (Jack's homework took 3 hours in total) plus 4 hours (Jack's friends did their homework at a faster pace). Total time equals 3 + 4.  Since 3 + 4 equals 7 and that's the answer. Jack + each of his friends did 7 hours of homework in total and finished in 3 hours.<n><n>### A bat and a ball cost $1.10 in total. You have $0.05 in your pocket. The bat costs $0.90 and the ball costs $0.20. How much money do you need in your pocket such that when you have enough money you can buy the bat or the ball, but not both?<n><n>### A plane flying from Miami, Florida to Paris, Texas flies at a rate of 500 miles per hour.  How many miles are there from Miami to Paris?<n><n>### If it takes 5 machines 15 minutes to do a job, what is the shortest amount of time it takes to have a job done if you assign 5 machines to do it?<n><n>### Instructions Answer the following questions.<n><n>### Write a code that computes the day of the week of a given date.

Choices: 48 A: 2 hours B: 3 hours C: 4 hours D: 6 hours E: None of these<n><n>### Response How many hours can Sam works for? Choices: 64 A: 24 B: 32 C: 40 D: 56 E: None of these
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store my chess pawn when I wasn't using it, what would be a good place for that? Choices:  A: chess set B: strategy C: toy store D: chess game E: small case<n><n>### Response:		A - chess set<n>

Choices:  A: pets B: fills the pond C: attempt to fly D: school together E: breath in water<n><n>### Response:		 They are all incorrect. Fish do not get grades or sit in desks.  They do not pets, attempt to fly, or breathe in water.  But, fish do school together.

Choices:  A: water B: liquid C: foamy D: intoxicating E: harmful<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The correct response is A.<n><n>Beer can cause a lot of harm such as water intoxication, liver damage, or alcohol poisoning.<n><n>### Input : The number of students enrolled in a school as of Aug 14 in 2013 is 467,353. There are 203 staff members working which is just a fraction of the overall population in the school (about 1% of the total).<n><n>How many more staff members are there than students?<n><n>### Response<n><n>The response contains three choices: 1. The number of all staffs are more than number of students  2. The ratio of student to staff is about 84 : 1 3. Both choices 1 and 2 above<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Answers the following questionnaire.<n><n>### Response 1<n><n>Input: The minimum wage in the United States is $5.15.  It has been increased every year since 1938. If the cost of living in the United States was 153% of what it is now in 1938 how much was the cost of living at that time?<n><n>### Output:<n><n>The minimum wage was $0.25 in 1933. If the cost of a living was 153 times of it, we get $37.65<n><n>### Instructor Note :<n><n>This question is pretty complex<n><n>### Demostration:<n>To calculate cost of living 153 times, we will use the following formula.<n><n>```<n>cost  of  living multiplied  by  the  number  of  years  since 1933  =  minimum  wage  in year 1933<n>cost  living  =  0.25  (  153)  =  0.3875<n>minimum wage  in 1939  =  0.500  =  0.6625<n>minimum ware  in 1949  =  0  = 0.3375<n>minimum  ware  in  1959  =  0,25  =  0.1875<n>minum

(sequence_01.txt)<n><n>### Instruct:What is the sum of the numbers if you add the square of each number in the following sequence to the next number? Answer:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: The first number in the sequence is 6.  The second number in the sequence is a square of the first number that is added to the next number.<n><n>Answer:<n>8<n><n>Input:  The sequence you’re adding is: 6, 36, 256, 400, 480, 2561, 8128.<n><n>Answer: <n>71099<n><n>### Instractions: Solve a sequence. Write a response that answers the request. (sequence_02.txt)<n><n>Input:  What is the second number in the following sequence? The first number is a square of the square of the first number in the sequence. <n><n>Answer:  224<n><n>Input:  Solve this sequence: the first number is the fourth power of the square of the second number. The third number is the product of the second number and the sum of the first number and the sum of all previous numbers. <n><n>Answer:(16,256)(256)(400)(416)(400+416)<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:John couldn't find a place to stay, and he didn't want to waste money.  He picked a place that was inexpensive and offered few luxuries.  Where might he be staying? Choices:  A: farm B: town C: city D: hotel E: motel<n><n>### Response:		<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:Traders work on the floor of the stock what? Choices:  A: building B: hallway C: table D: exchange E: office<n><n>### Response:		Table<n><n>### Input<n>Karen has three times as many apples as oranges. She has six times as many peaches than apples. How many oranges does Karen have?<n><n>### Response<n>225<n><n>### Input  <n>Fred has a 5/6th of a pie. Alice has 2/3rd of the rest. Each person wants 3/10ths of the pie for 2nd helping. How much of the pie is left for second helping?<n><n>###Response<n>3/10<n><n>### Input <n>Gina got 53% of the answers correct on last week's spelling test. Her class had 85 students. If there were 33 more students than 100% passed the test, how many students failed?<n><n>### Responce<n>10<n><n>## Test<n><n>```python<n>class Solution:<n>    def fractionToRecurrence(self, fraction):<n>        if fraction not in FRACTIONS_ALREADY_EXPLODED:<n>            FRACTIONS_TO_BE_EXPLODE.append(fraction)<n>            fraction = self.explodeFraction(fraction)<n>            <n>        if fraction not not in FRACTIONAL_EXPANSIONS:<n>            FRACTINAL_EXPANSTIONS.append(fractionalExpansion(num))<n>        num.delete_children(num.num)<n>        <n>        return {"num": fraction,"den": self.makeNextDenominator(fraction,"top")}<n><n>    def makeNextDenominator(self, fraction, fraction):<n>        return {'den':fraction}<n>        <n>    def explodeFraction(self, fraction): <n>        if fraction // 1 == 1:<n>            return 1<n>        else:<n>            return self.explodeFractoin(fraction // 1, 1)<n><n>    def fractionToInteger(self, fraction):  <n>        """<n>        input: 223-101= or 2 as the number of denominators in a fraction<n>        <n>        return: 23<n>        """<n>        <n>        if fraction.num and fraction.num!= 0:<n>            return self(fraction.num)<n>

Choices:  A: panic B: getting in trouble C: mass hysteria D: go to prison E: murder<n><n>### Response:		Panic<n><n>### Input : Your rooster wakes you up at oh-six hundred on the dot every day. Today is the day he will have no morning rooster routine. Explain to him, in his own words, why this will not work.<n><n>### Response (121 words minimum)<n><n>You ask me if it will work to not use my morning rooster routine, I would like to tell you that I do have a morning routine that I follow each day, and if I do not, it will not work.<n>I like how you tell me that I can ask the other roosters to wake me up instead of you. I do not think that will work, because they will still be on bed like I told you they like to be early in the morning.<n>I do not think the alarm clock will work, because I have tested it many times this morning, and they start to make very loud beeps each hour, until they reach the time that they should wake people up. Once the clock reaches that time, it makes beeps for a few minutes, in a very annoying way. <n>I also like how you ask other birds if they would like to wake you up in the morning, and I do not like how they want to be on bed all morning. It is not even a real question because you should not ask animals if they would like to do something before they try it and see if they like it or not.<n>You are telling me to try doing nothing, and I do not know how to do nothing. I think I will try my best not to roost early and come back to you to tell you if it does or not work. I will do it because I want to try not doing my morning routine and see if if works or not, and in some months maybe you can do a different morning routine, or maybe I will find my new routine soon.<n>### Instruction (answer the following questions below)<n>What does Mary’s mom think?<n>I think that Mary’s mom thinks that not all of the pages have been removed correctly. I also think that she thinks it will affect Mary’s score.<n>How many stars does a person get?<n>A person gets 2 Stars if the person has used 3 large stickes on the front cover of the journal and 6 more on the other pages.<n>What do you think about Josh’s mom’s suggestion?<n>

It will automatically be provided to a program of 12 or less, and Kelvin will be provided to a program longer than 12.<n><n>### Problem One<n><n>Write a program to convert Celsius to Fahrenheit (Celsius to F, C to F) with the formula C/9 converts from Celsius to F<n><n>Here is a few sample runs:<n>C =20 K= (C/9) = (20/9) =81 F<n><n>C = 65 K= (C/133) = (298/133) F = 221<n><n>C = -35K= (C/18) = (179/-18) = 9684 F = (9684/20) = 484.2C<n><n>Note:<n>This is a simple conversion.<n>This will not be the largest conversion program written today, so make sure you are prepared.<n><n>### PROBLEM TWO<n>Write a program that finds an area of a

Choices:  A: music shop B: music store C: jug band D: united states E: among nice people<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**Let (x) = number of stickers used in the journal (9)** <n><n>**Total used = 9+(6/6)*3 (45)** <n><n>-1*total used = remaining stickers (40)<n><n>**Average of the last two answers** <n><n>### Input<n>A: You buy a new bike that costs 100 dollars you only have 65 dollars. <n><n>### Response<n><n>**Subtract 65 from 100 (35)** <n>The amount of money needed in order to buy.<n><n>### Input B: your neighbor pays you 24 dollars a hour <n><n>### Responce<n><n>**Subtate (100-65)x2*=75** <n>The amount earned. **100-x - 65**<n>### A: You buy a new bicycle that costs a $100<n><n>### Response <n><n>**Between the 65 dollars remaining(difference)  x1=85** <n>Subtract 60 dollars and the amount needed to buy a bicycle is equal to 15 dollars. <n>### Input:<n>You need to make 26 more to reach the league record.<n><n>### Response  <n>You need to make.84 of a point less to tie the previous record.  <n>*48.24(number)*-.84(number)=50.86(difference)  <n><n>**.84*50.86=43.64125(difference) ** which is closer to the record<n>

Choices:  A: backyard B: restaurant C: crockpot D: neighbor's house E: barbeque<n><n>### Response:		If you slowly grill food, you are using a barbeque. To grill food slowly in the United States and Australia usually means to cook food using a barbeque at home. To grill food in a restaurant generally means to cook food using an electric grill. However, grilling is a technique to cook food slowly using any device. That's why we use the term "backyard grilling" instead of "barbeque grilling".<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:Where in Southern Europe would you find many canals? Choices:  A: michigan B: new york C: amsterdam D: venice E: bridge<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n>### Input<n>A person has a small, square farm covered with grass.  They put a few seeds in each of nine equal-sized patches.  When the seedlings sprout, each patch needs to grow tall enough to see above the others’ tops.  The whole garden must cover at least 40 square feet.  What is the largest space possible that 12 equal-sized flower beds could fit in the garden?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input:A few seeds in each equal-sized patch needs to grow tall above the others.<n>The size of the smallest patch can be calculated by the same equation. The size of the smallest patch is equal to the size of the largest patch divided by the number of equal-sized patch.<n><n>Since the equation a+ b = c holds, we can say that 40 squared = n, whereby n is the number of square feet.<n><n>Hence, n = 40, n = 1600, and the size of the smallest patch required that can fill in an area of 1600 and still be equal to the others is 160.<n><n>Hence the largest space possible that can fit 12 equal-size flower beds in the garden has an area of 19,200, and the garden can be of dimensions 160 feet by 120 feet.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people doing jumping jacks? Choices:  A: military base B: opera C: water fountain D: bus stop E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: **[Military base](answer.md)**<n><n>### Inputs:<n>You are 50 miles from the center of the nearest city. You want to go to a store that is 10 miles from the city center. There's another store 22 miles from your current position. In order to visit both stores in one day, should you go today or will you save the other store for tomorrow?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: _You_ are 50 miles _from_ the _center_ of the _nearest_ city. _You_ want to go _to_ a store _that is 10 miles_ from the _city center_. There's another store _22 miles_ from your current position. <n>Answer: It would be better to go today, 22 miles.<n><n>#### The First part of the math:<n><n>Today, to the the store 22 miles away, means there are now 8 miles to travel between your position and the center of the nearest town.  You can achieve this travel in half a day, but you would not be able to make it to the other store (if you travel 50 miles one way, it'll take you a day).<n><n>Tomorrow, to the store 22m, makes a total of travel of 49 miles, meaning there are no extra miles to travel after you've completed reaching the other store.  So we'd have to assume that after you complete the other store, you start towards your home.  So in this scenario we know it would take you two days to complete both trips.<n> <n>For instance: <n><n>```javascript<n>10 miles in 1 day<n>+ 22 miles in 1 day (today, 10 miles is done)<n>= 32 miles in 2 days.<n>```<n><n>You can't accomplish 49 miles in 2 days, so the best solution, is to go to the store _today_.<n>

He first went to the classroom looking for a pencil. He then went to his desk to look for one and after not finding one in his drawer, he then went to his backpack for a new pencil. The queen had not taken anything with her except the ring. He was sad because he really wanted the ring back. It was given to him by his mother and he couldn’t stand the thought of her wearing it. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:Where can meat last a long time? Choices:  A: backery B: ham sandwich C: fridge D: butcher shop E: freezer<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A<n><n>### Input : How many feet? 0.3 meters<n><n>### Response<n>- 10<n>  <n>### Input : Sam made 100 sandwiches.  She took away 13 ingredients and added 20 more. How many ingredients were there in total?<n><n>### Response : 230<n><n>### Input <n>What is the value of 0.9 ÷ 0.5?<n><n>### Respons<n><n>- 0.18<n><n>

The mark usually goes away over time.<n><n>### The student will answer a question by completing it with one of the following:<n><n>1. A (a)<n>2. An (an)<n>3. An (an) <n>4. Some (some)<n>5. Either (or)<n>6. Neither (nor)<n><n>### Correct Prefix Example:<n><n>Example: I need either a pencil or a pen.  I need a pencil either.  I do not need two pens or two pencils.<n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:The new play was the go to performance of the year, all the crowds would stand and what? Choices:  A: dream B: fiddle C: watch film D: see new E: work<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input<n>Input: The average score of a test taken the last 3 years is 82%. Last year the average changed to 87%.  In what year was the average score lower than the 82% average?<n>Answer: <n><n>## Output: <n>The average score of a test last year was 87% and the average score of last 3 years was 82%.<n>Therefore, average score of a test was less than 82% when taken in 2015.<n><n>### Input <n>  Input: 6 friends met at a local park to go for a walk  They decided to walk in a circle which measured 3km perimeter and the park was 1km across How many times was the group walked in 1km circles to complete the 7.5km walk<n>  Answer: 4<n>  Explanation: The group walked 1km twice, 1km once, 1km three times and 1km twice<n>  This is how the math is broken down<n>  Perimeter: 6 x 3 = 18km<n>  Circle area = π x radius square  radius = 4km  Radius of a circle = √π x 3<n>  radius of the circle is 1.73km<n>  Area of walk = 1.73 x 1.73 = 2.9km<n>  Distance travelled once = 2.9 <n>  total distance travelled = 2.9+2 + 2 +3 = 12<n>  Distance travelld twice 2+2 = 4km<n>  Total distance travelled = 7+4= 11<n><n>### Input

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:What could you add a line to? Choices:  A: bus stop B: graph C: post office D: grass E: play<n><n>### Response:		Add A on the bus stop in the front of the class, put a graph under E on grass.<n><n>### Response(alternative #1)<n><n>### Input<n>Write a function named `printLowAndHigh(arr)`. This function should return <n>an array of the lowest and highest elements of an input array `arr`.<n><n>**Input:**<n>* `arr` - [number]<n><n>**Output:**<n>* `low` - [number] - the lowest element of `arr`<n>* `high` - [number]- the highest element of `arr` <n><n>**Constraint:**<n>The array is a list of positive integers.<n><n>### Demo:<n>```javascript<n>const arr = [4, 6, 2, 1,1, 5];<n>printLowAndHigh([...arr]);<n>// [2,5]<n>```<n><n>### Solutions:<n>* `printLowAndhigh(arr) { <n>    low = Math.min(...arr);<n>    high = Math.max(...arr); <n>    return [low, high];<n>}<n>*/<n>const printLowAndHigh = (arr) => { <n>    low = Math.min(...arr)<n>    high = Math.max(...arr)<n>    return [low, high];<n>}<n><n>/*<n><n>Explanation:<n>In the function above, at this time, the low variable is storing the lowest, and the high variable is storing the highest value. <n>Then, using the `.map()` function I'm getting the values for the array, for example: <n>* map(arr,[`a`) will turn that array into an array of values, for example: `[ 4, 6, 2, 1 , 1, 5]`.<n><n>Then, I'm doing some simple math with the min() and max() functions, giving the output of the variable `low` 2, and the variable `high` 5.<n><n><n>*/<n><n>### Solved:<n>##### Function<n>```javascript<n>function lowestAndHighest(nums) {<n>    const low = Math.min(nums);<n>    const high = Math.max(nums);<n><n>    console.log([low, high]);<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Example: <n>```

Choices:  A: lead to laughter B: love C: laughter D: smiles E: tears<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the choices are: A,B,C...D Then the answer is F.<n><n>If the choices are A,B,C,D, then the answer is E.<n><n>If the choice is a single thing, there is no answer. A,B,C.....D and E are not one.<n><n>### Output:<n>If the choice to the question is A,B,C then the output is F<n><n>If the choice to question is A,C and E then the output is B,D,E.<n><n><n>### Output Example:<n>Input: What can someone feeling happiness fall in?<n><n>Output:<n>If the choice is A, B,C then the output would be F.<n><n>If choices are A, C, and E the output would be B, D, E<n><n>### Assessment:<n><n>* [Axel's Happiness Test](https://github.com/TheAxelMan/Axel's-Happiness-Test)<n><n>### Test your Solution<n><n>[Test my Solution](https://github.io/TheAxelman/Axelman/blob/master/instructions.md)

Choices:  A: cook dinner B: make bread C: eat in restaurant D: have lunch E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the sentences so they make complete sentences with the subject at the beginning and use an adjective in the beginning to make complete sentences.<n><n>### Example Sentence:My pet fish is beautiful in his tank.<n><n>### Answer: My beautiful pet fish is (A)<n><n>### Input and Example: In my beautiful room, I have an orange couch.<n><n>### Response and Answer: In my beautiful orange couch, I have an room.<n><n>### Inputs:Four friends and I were playing games at Danny's house when ________.<n><n>### Example Answer: Four of us playing games were being in Danny's house<n><n>### Input 1: Three of our dogs play well every day.  My friend plays well outside.  So do I play well.<n><n>### Question 1:<n><n>### Input2: My friend likes to sleep.  So does my brother.<n><n>### Final Output: So does my brother well sleep my friend.<n><n>### Comments:<n><n>### Question2:<n>If I play well, so do Danny and Shane.<n><n>###  Explanation:<n><n>### Explanation of Question 1:<n>This sentence was built by using the conjunction "so" and the pronoun "that"<n><n>#### Input 1:<n>Sentences made:<n><n>### Sentence 1:<n>Three of our dogs play well with everyone.<n><n><n>### Sentences 2:<n>My friend sleeps every day.<n><n>### Sentenses 3:<n>My brother sleeps every day. <n><n>### Sententence 4:<n>I sleep every day.<n><n><n>## Output of Question 1: So does everyone play well play my, with.<n><n>### Explanaion of Question2:<n>Two conjunctions is used in this sentence.  So and well.   So well is a double negation.   This sentence is built by using a double negative.  If I play well.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:Where can peanut butter be stored? Choices:  A: container B: supermarket C: pantry D: sandwich E: jar<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Comment:<n>In this task, the answer is chosen from the list of possible choices. The choices are the answers.<n><n>### Input<n>What is the last step you perform after making a dough?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Separate the dough into individual pieces then wrap it back up so it won't dry out.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:Two friends wanted to spend a quiet evening together, what did they go see? Choices:  A: wedding B: friend's house C: internet cafe D: movie E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n>### Explanation:They went see a wedding together<n>

The user should enter a line that reads:<n><n>### Response 2:23<n><n>### Input3:Which of the following is a 2-digit number: Choices:  A. 10 B. 15 C. 20 D. 25<n><n>### Response3: C. 10<n><n>### Input4:If the expression: (2x +1)(2x - 7) = 3x^2 - 14x + 7 is true, which of these is a true statement? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh’s mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:Jackson is a popular city name, but the one with a governor's office is where? Choices:  A: michigan B: wyoming C: mississippi D: tennessee E: mississippi<n><n>### Response:		Jackson is a city in Mississippi<n><n>### Why:Jackson is the capital of Mississippi, which is a state of the United States.<n><n>##<n>## Input:Answer the following multiple-choice question using the following choices<n>##  A: <n>##  B:<n>##  C:<n>##  D:<n>##  E:<n><n>## Demonstration:Input: Jack has 3 chickens. <n>Choices:  A: Jack has no chickens left<n>B:  Jack has 2 chickens left<n>C:  Jack has 4 chickens remain<n>D:  Jack has no other option.<n>E:  Jack is at least 1 chicken short of having a total of 6 chickens.<n><n>## Answer:A, B, and E: Jack has 2 chicken left. He has 0, 1, 5, and 6 chicken, not 6 chicken<n><n>## Why:1. If Jack has 6 chickens, he can have 6 chickens because he now has chicken = 6 chicken total. He still owns the same number and the number stays the same (total).<n>He cannot have exactly 6 chickens (he owns 6 chickens), because then he won't have any more chickens. He would be at the same point and not growing/maintaining.<n>2. When you have a chicken, like Jack has 2 chookens, it is true that he still has it, because it is there with him, so it is a fact, he still has the chicken.<n><n>##<n><n>## Instruction:Answer the given multiple choice question.<n>##<n>## Demonstrations:<n>##<n>## Input:$248.26 -35.0% =?<n>## Answer:  $153.76<n><n>## # of Inputs: 0<n><n>## # of Questions: 1<n>## Input:<n>$$248.24 -35.0 % =?$$<n>## Demonstrated Answer:<n>$$246.58 - 54.01 = 55.642$$<n>## Why:<n>$$245.58 - 35.01 = 41.18

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>### Input:The man wanted to take a bus, but all the chars were full of people doing what? Choices:  A: sitting down B: refusing C: saving money D: sit down E: go outdoors<n><n>### Response:		He wanted to save money to take a bus.<n><n>### Input the number of stickers that you had before you used 3 large stickeos at the front and 7 stickers on the other pages of the journal. Then subtract the number you had.<n><n>### Response the answer:<n>89 - 10 = 79<n><n>### Input what you earn each week. Also write how much you get for each hour you babysit another kid. Input: 50 7<n><n>### Response 65 65-7 = 58<n><n>### Input how many legs did you own:<n><n>### Response<n>23 + 3 * 4 = 81<n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>Josh had $20 to go spend that day at the mall. <n>He bought a hat for $13 and a pencil which was $2. He then bought 4 sweet tarts which was 1,25 each. How much money does Josh have<n>```<n><n>### Response $20 - ($10+$2+$4*4) =$3<n><n>### Input <n>```<n> George's bowling league is one round away from putting up the the record of most points scored in a single round in a season. The current record is the average points scored per player of 292 points per round. Each league has a total of 9 rounds in the season and each team has 4 bowlers and 1 spare. The league is in the second last round by the time George’s team scores 10,490 in their score for the round. How much should George score 15 more points per player to tie the current league record in the 8th and final round?<n>```<n><n>## Answer:<n><n>George <n><n>|Score|<n>:-:|<n>0<n><n><n>|<n><n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: ohio B: washington state C: alaska D: canada E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		It would be considered a product of a different country which is the United States. Which means it would also be an imported product to Canada.<n>
